descriptionSet.description: Regnard's name appears in the dedication on engraving n.3 (B192). His designs of Roman churches were first published in Varie bella inventioni de tempio ... (Paris Michel Vanlochom 1631); a more complete edition, containing 32 plates, was published as Praecipua urbis Romanae templa (Rome, 1650); finally, they were also included in Insignium Romae templorum prospectus exteriores interioresque ... ([Rome] Io. Iacobo de Rubeis 1684), containing 72 numbered plates. A comparison between the engravings listed here and those in the de Rossi edition (as listed in A-B), shows marked variants both in the text of the inscriptions and in the measurements.

inscription.text: [Vedute e giardini di Roma]
DISEGNO ET SITO DEL SONTUOSO GIARDINO ET PALAZZO DEL SER.MO GRAN DUCA DI TOSCANA. IN ROMA.
Disegno et sito del sontuoso Giardino et Palazzo del Serenissimo Gran Duca di Toscana. In Roma.
Disegno et sito del sontuoso Giardino et Palazzo del Ser(enissi)mo Gran Duca di Toscana. In Roma.

inscription.position: top right, first column from left
inscription.text: 1. 34 diverse statue antiche nella facciato del Palazzo tra guale le 4 da basso sono di porfido.

inscription.position: top right, first column from left
inscription.text: 2. Fontana con un Mercurio di metallo.

inscription.position: top right, first column from left
inscription.text: 3. Galleria doue sono 24 statue antiche et sopra ogni nichia y testa.

inscription.position: top right, first column from left
inscription.text: 4. Pili grandi antichi.

inscription.position: top right, first column from left
inscription.text: 5. Fontane di Musaia.

inscription.position: top right, first column from left
inscription.text: 6. spartimenti di semplici circondati da frutti nani.

inscription.position: top right, second column from left
inscription.text: 7. spartimenti di frutti et alberi nelli viali.

inscription.position: top right, second column from left
inscription.text: 8. Istoria di Niobe con le 14 figlioli di marmo grande al naturale

inscription.position: top right, second column from left
inscription.text: 9. Monte falto a mano in forma di Mausoleo cinto intorno con cipressi in cima del monte una fontana che sale dal condotto anticho dell acqua Vergine da 125 canne

inscription.position: top right, second column from left
inscription.text: 10. Cleopatra di marmo.
A I LETTORI
Ai lettori

Questo Palagio e situato nel Monte Pincio sottogiacendoui di veduta la maggior parte di Roma, la sua fabrica per tutto e ricca, ma nella parte verso il Giardino e stupendissima per la gran quantita di statue, et bassi rileui antichi in quella inseriti, della parte interna non ne diro altro rispondendo ella al resto, il che fa parimente la vaga galleria adornata di tante statue, dell'acque poi che con mirabil artificio si pel'Palagio, come pel'Giardino scorreno tacero, il qual Giardino per i politi viali per la diversa sorte d'arbori e floride herbe, e per i bei compartimenti, fonti, e statue sembra un paradiso terrestre.

inscription.text: [Vedute e giardini di Roma]
GIARDINO DEL ILL.mo CARD. MONTALTO
Giardino del Illustrissimo Cardinalis Montalto
Giardino del Ill.[ustrissi]mo Card.[inalis] Montalto

Questo e quel bellissimo giardino fatto da Papa Sisto V. con li suoi Palazzi et ornamenti di Statue antiche e moderne in gran numero, Peschiera, Horto, Vigna ecasamenti, ogni cosa con mirabil arte et industria abellita et poi dal Ill.mo Card. Montalto arrichita et accrescuita de molte Statue et altri richissimi ornamenti. Vi e congiunta la vigna qual in questo disgeno non e compresa per il gran circuito di essa, dentro vista sulla collina la bellissima statua che dalla Porta quirinale per il dritto viale si scopre dietro la chiesa di S. Ant.o

Questo e quel bellissimo giardino fatto da Papa Sisto V. con li suoi Palazzi et ornamenti di Statue antiche e moderne in gran numero, Peschiera, Horto, Vigna ecasamenti, ogni cosa con mirabil arte et industria abellita et poi dal Illustrissimo Cardinalis Montalto arrichita et accrescuita de molte Statue et altri richissimi ornamenti. inscription.text: Praecipua aliquot Romanae antiquitatis ruinarum monimenta, vivis prospectibus, ad veri imitationem affabre designata
EX VARIIS, APUD CAPITOLIUM RUINIS, PROSPECTUS UNUS
Ex variis, apud Capitolium ruinis, prospectus unus
Various ruins near the Capitol, Prospect 1
T
IMP. CAES. LUCIO SEPTIMIO M FIL. SEVERO PIO PERTINACI AUG. PATRI PATRIAE PATICO ARABICO...
Imperatori Caesari Lucio Septimio Marci filio Severo Pio Pertinaci Augusto patri patriae Parthico Arabico...

Imp(eratori) Caes(ari) Lucio Septimio M(arci) | fil(io) Severo Pio Pertinaci | Aug(usto) patri patriae Pa(r)t(h)ico | Arabico...
NOTE: This print only includes the beginning of the inscription as it appears on the Arch of Septimius Severus. The 'N' in Pertinaci is reversed. See Source Text below. The full inscription can be found on prints A12, A38, A56, C404.

Ìmp(eratori) Caes(ari) Lucio Septimio M(arci) fil(io) Severo Pio Pertinaci Aug(usto) patri patriae Parthico Arabico et
Parthico Adiabenico, pontific(i) maximo, tribunic(ia) potest(ate) X̅I̅, ìmp(eratori) X̅I̅, co(n)s(uli) I̅I̅I̅, proco(n)s(uli) et
Ìmp(eratori) Caes(ari) M(arco) Aurelio L(uci) fil(io) Antonino Aug(usto) Pio Felici, tribunic(ia) potest(ate) V̅I̅, co(n)s(uli), proco(n)s(uli), 《p(atri) p(atriae)》,
《optimis fortissimisque principibus》
5 ob rem publicam restitutam imperiumque populi Romani propagatum
insignibus virtutibus eorum domi forisque s(enatus) p(opulus)q(ue) R(omanus).
{CIL VI.1033 cf. VI 31230 et VI 36881 et VI p. 4318 et VI p. 4351 (ad 36881)}

To the Emperor Caesar Lucius Septimius Severus, son of Marcus, Pius, Pertinax, Augustus, Pater Patriae, Parthicus Arabicus and Parthicus Adiabenicus, Pontifex Maximus, granted the Tribunician power for the eleventh time, acclaimed victorius general for the eleventh time, consul for the third time, proconsul; and to the Emperor Caesar Marcus Aurelius Antoninus, son of Lucius, Augustus, Pius, Felix, granted the Tribunician power for the sixth time, consul, proconsul, Pater Patriae; to both men, the best and bravest emperors, for having saved the Republic and expanded the dominion of the Roman people and for their remarkable virtue, at home and abroad, the Senate and the People of Rome (dedicate this arch).

inscription.text: [Urbis Romae aedificorum illustriumque supersunt reliquae]

Jani templum marmoreum in Foro Boario, prope Sanctu[m] Georgiu[m] in Velabro, quattuor habens portas, et in frontispicio cuiusq[ue] duodecim fenestellas, quae quattuor anni tempora cum duodecim mensibus designant.

Jani templum marmoreum in Foro Boario, prope Sanctum Georgium in Velabro, quattuor habens portas, et in frontispicio cuiusque duodecim fenestellas, quae quattuor anni tempora cum duodecim mensibus designant.

Jani templum marmoreum in Foro Boario, prope Sanctu[m] Georgiu[m] in Velabro, quattuor habens portas, et in frontispicio cuiusq[ue] duodecim fenestellas, quae quattuor anni tempora cum duodecim mensibus designant.

The marble temple of Janus in the Forum Boarium, near San Giorgio in Velabro, has four gates and in the frontispiece of each of them there are 12 niches which designate the four seasons of the year with the 12 months.

inscription.text: [Urbis Romae aedificorum illustriumque supersunt reliquae]
Junonis templum, sive, Mercurii ut quidam scripserunt, incendio consumptum, et restitutum a Septimio Imp. cuius pro foribus porticus variis columnis ornata hodie cernitur
Junonis templum, sive, Mercurii ut quidam scripserunt, incendio consumptum, et restitutum a Septimio Imperatore cuius pro foribus porticus variis columnis ornata hodie cernitur
Junonis templum, sive, Mercurii ut quidam scripserunt, incendio consumptum, et restitutum a Septimio Imp(eratore) cuius pro foribus porticus variis columnis ornata hodie cernitur
Temple of Juno or Mercury, as some wrote, consumed by fire and restored by Emperor Septimius Severus, whose colonnade next to the forums can be seen today adorned with several columns.

IMP. CAES. L. SEPTIMIUS SEVERUS PIUS PERTINAX AUG. ARABIC. ADIABENIC. PARTHIC MAXIMUS PONTIFEX. TRIB. POT. XI. COS. III. ET. IMP CAES. M. AURELIUS ANT. PIUS FELIX PONT. MAX TRIB. POT. VI. COS. PROCOS. P.P. INCENDIO CONSUMPTAM RESTITUERUNT

Imperator Caesar Lucius Septimius Severus Pius Pertinax Augustus Arabicus Adiabenicus Parthicus Maximus Pontifex Tribunicia Potestas XI Consul III et Imperator Caesar Marcus Aurelius Antoninus Pius Felix Pontifex Maximus Tribunicia Potestate VI Proconsul Pater Patriae Incendio consumptam restituerunt

Imp(erator) Caes(ar) L(ucius) Septimius Severus Pius Pertinax Aug(ustus) Arabic(us) Adiabenic(us) Parthic(us) Maximus | Pontifex trib(unicia) pot(estas) XI co(n)s(ul) III et Imp(erator) Caes(ar) M(arcus) Aurelius Ant(oninus) Pius Felix Pont(ifex) Max(imus) | trib(unicia) pot(estas) VI co(n)s(ul) proco(n)s(ul) p(ater) p(atriae) incendio consumptam restituerunt.
NOTE: This inscription as it appears in this print differs slightly from the original inscription. In the first line on this print, the title "Felix" is missing between "Pius" and "Pertinax". In the second line on the print, the first word "Pontifex" is an erroneous inclusion. Missing in the second line are the phrases "imp(erator) XI" and "P(ater) P(atriae)." The title of the emperor Commodus also diverge from the original. "Antoninus" is erroneously abbreviated in the print and the title "Aug(ustus)" is missing, while "Pontifex Maximus" and "P(ater) P(atriae)" are erroneous inclusions. Compare this transcription with the Source Text below.

Imp(erator) Caes(ar) L(ucius) Septi̲mius Severus, Pius, Felix, Pertinax, Aug(ustus), Arabic(us), Adia̲b̲e̲n̲i̲c̲(us), Par̲thic(us) Maximus,
trib(unicia) potest(ate) X̅I̅, imp(erator) X̅I̅, co(n)s(ul) I̅I̅I̅, p(ater) p(atriae), et
Imp(erator) Caes(ar) M(arcus) Aurelius Antoninus, Pius, Felix, Aug(ustus), [trib(unicia) pot(estate) V̅I̅], co(n)s(ul), proco(n)sul
incendio corruptam restit̲u̲e̲r̲̲u̲n̲t̲.
{CIL VI 1034 = VI 31231 cf. VI p. 3777 et VI p. 4318 = IX 222*}

Emperor Caesar Lucius Septimius Severus Pius, Felix, Pertinax, Augustus, Arabicus, Adiabenicus, Parthicus Maximus, holding tribunician power for the eleventh year, imperator for the eleventh time, three times consul, father of the fatherland, and the Emperor Caesar Marcus Aurelius Antoninus Pius, Felix, Augustus, holding the tribunician power for the sixth year, consul, proconsul, restored [this building] after it had been consumed by fire.

inscription.text: [Urbis Romae aedificorum illustriumque supersunt reliquae]

Templum inter vetusta Urbis templa, hodie nobilissimu[m] fere integra, quod omnibus Diis Sacru[m] esset, Pantheon vocatum et a M. Agrippa, propre Thermas Agrippinas, hodie la Ciambella, dicatum sphaerica forma vulgo S. Maria Rotonda vocant.

Templum inter vetusta Urbis templa, hodie nobilissimum fere integra, quod omnibus Diis Sacrum esset, Pantheon vocatum et a Marcus Agrippa, propre Thermas Agrippinas, hodie la Ciambella, dicatum sphaerica forma vulgo Santa Maria Rotonda vocant.

Templum inter vetusta Urbis templa, hodie nobilissimu[m] fere integra, quod omnibus Diis Sacru[m] esset, Pantheon vocatum et a M.[arcus] Agrippa, propre Thermas Agrippinas, hodie la Ciambella, dicatum sphaerica forma vulgo S.[anta] Maria Rotonda vocant.

One of the most ancient temples of the City—today the most noble one and almost undamaged—, called Pantheon as it was consecrated to all gods, and conveniently named Thermae Agrippinae by Marcus Agrippa—today La Ciambella—; it is denominated vulgarly Santa Maria Rotonda because of its spherical form.

Templi Pacis, a Claudio Imperatore inchoati, et a Vespasiano perfecti, quae supersunt, ruinae, aliquibus maximus pulcherrimisque reliquis columnis in hoc vasa et ornamenta templi Hierosolymitani servabantur.

Templi Pacis, a Claudio Imp[eratore] inchoati, et a Vespasiano perfecti, quae supersunt, ruinae, aliquibus maximus pulcherrimisq[ue] reliquis columnis in hoc vasa et ornamenta templi Hierosolymitani servabantur.

The surviving ruins of the Temple of Peace which was initiated by emperor Claudius and finished by Vespasian, with some tall and beautiful remaining columns, in which the vessels and ornaments of the temple of Jerusalem were used.

Pars Fori Traiani, quod inter Nervae Foru[m], Capitolium, et collem Quirinalem, ab Apollodoro architecto mira arte extructum fuit, cuiusq[ue] frontispiciu[m] in aliquibus Traiani nomismatisbus et aureis et aereis cernitur.

description.source: Hilary Barker

descriptionSet.description: Although the inscription at the bottom of the print identifies this as a view of the Forum of Trajan, it actually depicts the Forum of Nerva also called the Forum Transitorium. Regarding the dedicatory inscription which appears on the accumbent slab in the center of the print, it is unclear why this particular inscription, which was found in Ferentium, was added to this view. It is possible that the engraver or designer had seen it elsewhere or in an epigraphic sylloge. The presence of another sculptural fragment next to it indicates a certain degree of inventiveness on the part of the engraver.

Imp(erator) Nerva Caesar Au[gustus]... trib(unicia) potest(ate) II Imp(erator)...
NOTE: The inscription as it appears on this print differs from the original, likely because it was fragmentary and difficult to read. See Source Text below for the modern scholarly reconstruction.

The Emperor Nerva Caesar Augustus Germanicus, pontifex maximus, invested with the tribunician power for the second time, having been consul four times, father of the fatherland, built the Forum of Minerva.
SALUTI PUBLICAE SACRUM QUINTIUS C.F. LATINA CESTIANUS DUCENIUS PROCULUS
Saluti publicae sacrum Quintius Caii filius Latina Cestianus Ducenius Proculus

Saluti Publ | icae sacrum | Quintius C(aii) f(ilius) | [Pa]latina | Cestianus Duce | nius Proculus
NOTE: While this print does not observe the line breaks of the original inscription, it does not otherwise diverge from it.

Saluti Publicae
sacrum
[-- -] Quintius C(ai) f(ilius)
[Pa]latina
Cestianus
Ducenius
Proculus
{CIL X 5821 cf. X p. 1013}
Quintius Cestianus Ducenius Proculus, son of Gaius, of the tribe of the Palatina, consecrated [this] to Salus Publica

Insulae Tiberinae pars, quae pontem Cestium, nunc Sancti Bartholomei, respicit. Aesculapio olim Sacra habet biremis formam ubi latissima est, erceli iactum non excedit longitudo Stadia circiter duo complectitur.

Insulae Tiberinae pars, quae pontem Cestium, nunc Sancti Bartholomei, respicit. Aesculapio olim Sacra habet biremis formam ubi latissima est, erceli iactum non excedit longitudo Stadia circiter duo complectitur.

Part of the Tiber Island which looked at the Cestius—now St. Bartholomew—Bridge. Dedicated once to Asclepius, it has the form of a two-oared boat; in its widest part, it does not exceed the throw of a small spear, and its length approximately is two stadia.

descriptionSet.description: Although the inscription at the bottom of the print identifies the buildings represented as the ruins of the Temple of Concord, they are actually the Temple of Saturn (left) and the Temple of Vespasian and Titus (right). The Temple of Concord is actually just north (right in the print) of the Temple of Vespasian and Titus, and today only the concrete core of the podium survives.

...restituerunt...

I̲m̲p̲(eratores) C̲a̲e̲s̲s̲. S̲e̲v̲e̲r̲u̲s̲ e̲t̲ A̲n̲t̲o̲n̲i̲n̲u̲s P̲i̲i̲ F̲e̲l̲i̲c̲(es) A̲u̲g̲g. r̲estituer(unt).
{CIL VI 938 cf. VI 31210 et VI p. 3777 et VI 4308}
The Emperors Caesar Severus and Caesar Antoninus, the pious and fortunate Augusti, restored it.

inscription.text: [Urbis Romae aedificorum illustriumque supersunt reliquae]
Arcus Septimii Imp. ad clivum Capitolinum, in quo incisae sunt alatae victoriae, cum trophaeis et terrestris, navalisque belli Simulacra, omnium integerrimus hodie extat.
Arcus Septimii Imperatoris ad clivum Capitolinum, in quo incisae sunt alatae victoriae, cum trophaeis et terrestris, navalisque belli Simulacra, omnium integerrimus hodie extat.
Arcus Septimii Imp(eratoris) ad clivum Capitolinu(m), in quo incisae sunt alatae victoriae, cu(m) trophaeis et terrestris, navalisq(ue) belli Simulacra, omnium integerrimus hodie extat.

Arch of Emperor Septimius on the slope of the Capitoline Hill, in which images of winged Victories are carved, trophies, and representations of naval and land battles; today this is the most complete of all (ancient arches).

Imp Caes Lucio Septimio M fil Severo Pio Pertinaci Aug patri patriae Parthico Arabico et Parthico Adiabenico pontific maximo tribunic potest XI Imp XI cos III procos et imp Caes M Aurelio L Fil Antonino Aug Pio Felici tribunic potest VI cos procos p p optimis fortissimisque principibus ob rem publicam restitutam imperiumque populi romani propagatum insignibus virtutibus eorum domi forisque SPQR

Imperatori Caesari Lucio Septimio Marci filio Severo Pio Pertinaci Augusto patri patriae Parthico Arabico et Parthico Adiabenico pontifici maximo tribunicia potestate XI Imperatori XI consuli III proconsuli et Imperatori Caesari Marco Aurelio Lucii filio Antonino Augusto Pio Felici tribunicia potestate VI consuli proconsuli patri patriae optimis fortissimisque principibus ob rem publicam restitutam imperiumque populi romani propagatum insignibus virtutibus eorum domi forisque Senatus Populusque Romanus

Imp(eratori) Caes(ari) Lucio Septimio M(arci) fil(io) Severo Pio Pertinaci Aug(usto), patri patriae, Parthico Arabico et | Parthico Adiabenico, pontific(i) max(imo), tribunic(ia) potest(ate) XI, imp(eratori) XI, co(n)s(uli) III, proco(n)s(uli), et | Imp(eratori) Caes(ari) M(arco) Aurelio L(ucii) f(ilio) Antonino Aug(usto) Pio Felici, tribunic(ia) potest(ate) VI, co(n)s(uli), proco(n)s(uli), p(atri) p(atriae), | optimis fortissimisque principibus, | ob rem publicam restitutam imperiumque populi romani propagatum | insignibus virtutibus eorum domi forisque, S(enatus) P(opulus)Q(ue) R(omanus)

Ìmp(eratori) Caes(ari) Lucio Septimio M(arci) fil(io) Severo Pio Pertinaci Aug(usto) patri patriae Parthico Arabico et
Parthico Adiabenico, pontific(i) maximo, tribunic(ia) potest(ate) X̅I̅, ìmp(eratori) X̅I̅, co(n)s(uli) I̅I̅I̅, proco(n)s(uli) et
Ìmp(eratori) Caes(ari) M(arco) Aurelio L(uci) fil(io) Antonino Aug(usto) Pio Felici, tribunic(ia) potest(ate) V̅I̅, co(n)s(uli), proco(n)s(uli), 《p(atri) p(atriae)》,
《optimis fortissimisque principibus》
5 ob rem publicam restitutam imperiumque populi Romani propagatum
insignibus virtutibus eorum domi forisque s(enatus) p(opulus)q(ue) R(omanus).
{CIL VI.1033 cf. VI 31230 et VI 36881 et VI p. 4318 et VI p. 4351 (ad 36881)}

To the Emperor Caesar Lucius Septimius Severus, son of Marcus, Pius, Pertinax, Augustus, Pater Patriae, Parthicus Arabicus and Parthicus Adiabenicus, Pontifex Maximus, granted the Tribunician power for the eleventh time, acclaimed victorius general for the eleventh time, consul for the third time, proconsul; and to the Emperor Caesar Marcus Aurelius Antoninus, son of Lucius, Augustus, Pius, Felix, granted the Tribunician power for the sixth time, consul, proconsul, Pater Patriae; to both men, the best and bravest emperors, for having saved the Republic and expanded the dominion of the Roman people and for their remarkable virtue, at home and abroad, the Senate and the People of Rome (dedicate this arch).

inscription.text: [Urbis Romae aedificorum illustriumque supersunt reliquae]
Septizonii, quod Septimius Severus Imp. in via Appia extruxit, è regione templi divi Gregorii, tres veluti Zonae, quae hodie supersunt, columnarum pulchritudine et magnificentia spectabiles
Septizonii, quod Septimius Severus Imperator in via Appia extruxit, è regione templi divi Gregorii, tres veluti Zonae, quae hodie supersunt, columnarum pulchritudine et magnificentia spectabiles
Septizonii, quod Septimius Severus Imp[erator] in via Appia extruxit, è regione templi divi Gregorii, tres veluti Zonae, quae hodie supersunt, columnarum pulchritudine et magnificentia spectabiles

The three so called belts of the Septizonium—built by emperor Semptimius Severus in Via Appia—, seen from the direction of the temple of St. Gregory, that survived till today, notable because of the beauty and magnificence of its columns.

inscription.text: [Urbis Romae aedificorum illustriumque supersunt reliquae]

Moles lateritia semidiruta in via Praenestina, propè templu[m] nu[n]c S. Eusebii in qua duo trophaea marmorea erecta, hoc est, tranci cu[m] Spoliis excitati cernu[n]tur. Haec a C. Mario Cimbrico triumpho erecta fuisse dicuntur.

Moles lateritia semidiruta in via Praenestina, propè templum nunc Sancti Eusebii in qua duo trophaea marmorea erecta, hoc est, tranci cum Spoliis excitati cernuntur. Haec a Caio Mario Cimbrico triumpho erecta fuisse dicuntur.

Moles lateritia semidiruta in via Praenestina, propè templu[m] nu[n]c S[ancti] Eusebii in qua duo trophaea marmorea erecta, hoc est, tranci cu[m] Spoliis excitati cernu[n]tur. Haec a C[aio] Mario Cimbrico triumpho erecta fuisse dicuntur.

Semi-destroyed brick structure in via Praenestina next to the temple now dedicated to St. Eusebius, in which two elevated marble trophies can be seen, that is, two raised trunks with booty [weapons and shields]. It is told that they were erected by Caius Marius to celebrate his triumph against the Cimbri.

inscription.text: [Urbis Romae aedificorum illustriumque supersunt reliquae]

Ductus aquae fontiu(m) Caerulei et Curtii, Anienis quoq[ue] noni, a Caligula Imp. inchoatus, et a Claudio absolutus, aqua Claudia inde dictus, a porta Esqilina per Coelii montis dorsum in Aventinum perducebatur. hodie porta Maior appellatur.

Ductus aquae fontium Caerulei et Curtii, Anienis quoque noni, a Caligula Imperator inchoatus, et a Claudio absolutus, aqua Claudia inde dictus, a porta Esqilina per Coelii montis dorsum in Aventinum perducebatur. Hodie porta Maior appellatur.

Ductus aquae fontiu(m) Caerulei et Curtii, Anienis quoq(ue) noni, a Caligula Imp(erator) inchoatus, et a Claudio absolutus, aqua Claudia inde dictus, a porta Esqilina per Coelii montis dorsum in Aventinum perducebatur. Hodie porta Maior appellatur.

Aqueduct of the springs of the Caeruleus and the Curtius, and of the Anio Novus, initiated by emperor Caligula and finished by Claudius—and thus called Aqua Claudia—, which is lead from the Porta Esquilina through the back of the Caelian Hill till the Aventine. It is called today Porta Maggiore.

Ti Claudius Drusi f Cæisar Augustus Germanicus pontif. maxim. tribunicia potestate XII cos V imperator XXVII pater patriae aquas claudiam ex fontibus qui vocabantur Caeruleus et Curtius a milliario XXXXV item Anienem Novam a milliario LXII sua impensa in urbem perducendas curavit

Tiberius Claudius Drusi filius Cæisar Augustus Germanicus Pontifex maximus tribunicia potestate XII consul V imperatoR XXVII pater patriae Aquas Claudiam ex fontibus qui vocabantur Caeruleus et Curtius a milliario XXXXV item Anienem Novam a milliario LXII sua impensa in urbem perducendas curavit.

Ti(berius) Claudius Drusi f(ilius) Cæisar Augustus Germanicus pontif(ex) maxim(us) | tribunicia potestate XII co(n)s(ul) V imperator XXVII pater patriae | Aquas Claudiam ex fontibus qui vocabantur Caeruleus et Curtius a milliario XXXXV | item anienem novam a milliario LXII sua impensa in urbem perducendas curavit.

Tiberius Claudius Caesar Augustus Germanicus, son of Drusus, Pontifex Maximus, invested with the tribunican power twelve times, consul for the 5th time, hailed imperator 27 times, father of the fatherland, provided for at his own expense that the Claudian Aqueduct be brought from the 45th milestone, from the springs which are called the Caeruleus and the Curtius, and also that the Anio Novus be brought from the 62nd milestone into the city of Rome.

〈:in utroque latere〉
Ti(berius) Claudius Drusi f(ilius) Caisar Augustus Germanicus, pontif(ex) maxim(us),
tribunicia potestate X̅I̅I̅, co(n)s(ul) V̅, imperator X̅X̅V̅I̅I̅, pater patriae,
aquas Claudiam ex fontibus, qui vocabantur Caeruleus et Curtius, a milliario XXXXV,
item Anienem Novam, a milliario LXII, sua impensa, in urbem perducendas curavit.
{CIL VI 1256 cf. VI p. 3129 et VI p. 3798 et VI p. 4365}

Imp. Caesar Vespasianus August. pontif. max. trib. pot. II imp. VI cos. III desig. IIII p.p. Aquas Curtiam et caeruleam perductas a Divo Claudio et postea intermissas dilapsas que per annos novem sua impensa urbi restituit.

Imperator Caesar Vespasianus Augustustus pontifex maximus tribunicia potestate II imperator VI consul III designatus IIII pater patriae Aquas Curtiam et Caeruleam perductas a Divo Claudio et postea intermissas dilapsas que per annos novem sua impensa urbi restituit.

Imp(erator) Caesar Vespasianus August(us) pontif(ex) max(imus) trib(unicia) pot(estate) II imp(erator) VI co(n)s(ul) III desig(natus) IIII p(ater) p(atriae) | aquas Curtiam et Caeruleam perductas a Divo Claudio et postea intermissas dilapsasque | per annos novem sua impensa urbi restituit.

The Emperor Caesar Vespasian Augustus, pontifex maximus, invested with the tribunican power two times, hailed imperator six times, consul-elect for the 4th time, father of the fatherland, restored at his own expense for the city of Rome the aqueducts led from the Curtius and Caerulus by the divine Claudius and since interrupted and ruined for nine years.

〈:in utroque latere〉
Imp(erator) Caesar Vespasianus August(us), pontif(ex) max(imus), trib(unicia) pot(estate) I̅I̅, imp(erator) V̅I̅, co(n)s(ul) I̅I̅I̅, desig(natus) I̅I̅I̅I̅, p(ater) p(atriae),
aquas Curtiam et Caeruleam perductas a divo Claudio et postea intermissas dìlapsasque
per annos novem sua impensa urbi restituit.
{CIL VI 1257 cf. VI p. 3129 et VI p. 3798 et VI p. 4365}

Imp. T. Caesar Divi f. Vespasianus Augustus pontifex maximus tribunic. potestate X imperator XVII pater patriae censor cos. VIII Aquas Curtiam et Caeruleam perducatas a Divo Claudio et postea a Divo Vespasiano patre suo urbi restitutas cum a capite aquarum a solo vetustate dilapsae essent nova forma reducendas sua impensa curavit.

Imperator Titus Caesar divi filius Vespasianus Augustus pontifex maximus tribunicia potestate X imperator XVII pater patriae censor consul VIII Aquas Curtiam et Caeruleam perducatas a Divo Claudio et postea a Divo Vespasiano patre suo urbi restitutas cum a capite aquarum a solo vetustate dilapsae essent nova forma reducendas sua impensa curavit.

Imp(erator) T(itus) Caesar divi f(ilius) Vespasianus Augustus pontifex maximus tribunic(ia) | potestate X imperator XVII pater patriae censor co(n)s(ul) VIII | aquas Curtiam et Caeruleam perductas a divo Claudio et postea | a Divo Vespasiano patre suo urbi restitutas cum a capite aquarum a solo vetustate dilapsae essent nova forma reducendas sua impensa curavit.

Emperor Titus Claudius Vespasian Augustus, son of the divine Vespasian, pontifex maximus, invested with the tribunican power ten times, hailed imperator seventeen times, father of the fatherland, censor, consul for the 8th time, at his own expense provided that the Curtian and Caerulean waters that had been brought forth by the divine Claudius and afterwards had been restored for the city of Rome by his father the divine Vespasian, since they had falled into disrepair at the source of the waters from the very foundation because of age, be brought back again but in a new channel.

〈:in utroque latere〉
Imp(erator) T(itus) Caesar dìvì f(ilius) Vespasianus Augustus, pontifex maximus, tribunic(ia)
potestate X̅, imperator X̅V̅I̅I̅, pater patriae, censor, co(n)sul V̅I̅II̅
aquas Curtiam et Caeruleam perductas a dìvo Claudio et postea
a dìvo Vespasiano, patre suo, urbi restitutas, cum a capite aquarum a solo vetustate dìlapsae essent, nova forma reducendas sua impensa curavit.
{CIL VI 1258 cf. VI p. 3129 et VI p. 3798 et VI p. 4365}

descriptionSet.description: The Arch of Titus is shown here with encumbering constructions. In the medieval period it was built into the fortress of the Frangipani family. The arch was freed from later constructions and restored in 1822. For further information see Richardson, pg. 30, s.v. Arcus Titi (2).

inscription.text: Arcus marmoreus, omnium qui extant, antiquissimus, à Tito Vespasiano devictis Hierosolymis prope via(m) Sacram extructus: in cuius altera parte, victoriae insignia cu(m) arca foederis sculpta sunt in altera, triumphus Imp. cum aureo candelabro, et duabus Mosis tabulis.

Arcus marmoreus, omnium qui extant, antiquissimus, à Tito Vespasiano devictis Hierosolymis prope viam Sacram extructus: in cuius altera parte, victoriae insignia cum arca foederis sculpta sunt in altera, triumphus Imperator cum aureo candelabro, et duabus Mosis tabulis.

Arcus marmoreus, omnium qui extant, antiquissimus, à Tito Vespasiano devictis Hierosolymis prope via(m) Sacram extructus: in cuius altera parte, victoriae insignia cu(m) arca foederis sculpta sunt in altera, triumphus Imp(erator) cum aureo candelabro, et duabus Mosis tabulis.

Marble arch, the most ancient of all the surviving ones, built by Titus Vespasian next to the Via Sacra after the conquest of the people of Jerusalem; on one of its sides, the emblems of victory are carved, with the Ark of the Covenant; on the other side, the Emperor’s triumph with the golden menora and two tablets of Moses.
Senatus Populus que Romanus Divo Tito Divi Vespasiani f Vespasiano Augusto
Senatus Populusque Romanus Divo Tito Divi Vespasiani filio Vespasiano Augusto
Senatus | Populusque Romanus | Divo Tito Divi Vespasiani f(ilio) | Vespasiano Augusto
The Senate and the People of Rome (dedicate this arch) to the Divine Titus Vespasian Augustus, son of the Divine Vespasian.

Senatus
populusque Romanus
Dìvo Tito Dìvì Vespasianì f(ilio)
Vespasiano Augusto.
{CIL VI 945 cf. VI 31211 et VI p. 3777 et VI p. 4308}

inscription.text: Arcus triumphalis marmoreus in via Flaminia, Domitiano Imp. dicatus, ut vulgo putant, quod is multos ubiq[ue] arcus excitaverit nulla tamen in eo inscriptio apparet cernitur hodie inter Sacras aedes Sanctorum Silvestri, et laurentii in Lucina

Arcus triumphalis marmoreus in via Flaminia, Domitiano Imperatore dicatus, ut vulgo putant, quod is multos ubique arcus excitaverit nulla tamen in eo inscriptio apparet cernitur hodie inter Sacras aedes Sanctorum Silvestri, et laurentii in Lucina

Arcus triumphalis marmoreus in via Flaminia, Domitiano Imp[eratore] dicatus, ut vulgo putant, quod is multos ubiq[ue] arcus excitaverit nulla tamen in eo inscriptio apparet cernitur hodie inter Sacras aedes Sanctorum Silvestri, et laurentii in Lucina

Marble triumphal arch in Via Flaminia, dedicated to emperor Domitian, as it is commonly thought, because he inspired many arches everywhere; however, no inscription appears in it. Today it is seen between the sacred homes of S. Silvestre and S. Lorenzo in Lucina.

inscription.text: [Urbis Romae aedificorum illustriumque supersunt reliquae]

Constantini Imp. arcus ad angulum palatini montis propè Amphitheatrum omnium, qui supersunt integerimus, hunc Constantinus a Traiano Imp. inchoatum, superato ad Milvium pontem Mezentio, sibi consituit, adiectis eius victoriae insignibus.

Constantini Imperatoris arcus ad angulum palatini montis propè Amphitheatrum omnium, qui supersunt integerimus, hunc Constantinus a Traiano Imperatore inchoatum, superato ad Milvium pontem Mezentio, sibi consituit, adiectis eius victoriae insignibus.

Constantini Imp(eratoris) arcus ad angulum palatini montis propè Amphitheatru(m) omnium, qui supersu(n)t integerimus, hunc Constantinus a Traiano Imp(eratore) inchoatu(m), superato ad Milvium pontem Mezentio, sibi consituit, adiectis eius victoriae insignibus.

Arch of emperor Constantine at the corner of the Palatine Hill next to the Amphitheatre, the most complete of all the surviving ones. Constantine constructed for himself the arch that was initiated by emperor Trajan, after his victory over Maxentius at the Milvian Bridge, adding the trophies of his victory.

IMP. CAES. FL. CONSTANTINO MAXIMO P. F. AUGUSTO S.P.Q.R. QUOD INSTINCTU DIVINITATIS MENTIS MAGNITUDINE CUM EXERCITU SUO TAMDE TYRANNO QUAM DE OMNI EIUS FACTIONE UNO TEMPORE IUSTIS REM PUBLICAM ULTUS EST ARMIS ARCUM TRIUMPHIS INSIGNEM DICAVIT.

IMPERATORI CAESARI FLAVIO CONSTANTINO MAXIMO PIO FELICI AUGUSTO SENATUS POPULUSQUE ROMANO QUOD INSTINCTU DIVINITATIS MENTIS MAGNITUDINE CUM EXERCITU SUO TAM DE TYRANNO QUAM DE OMNI EIUS FACTIONE UNO TEMPORE IUSTIS REMPUBLICAM ULTUS EST ARMIS ARCUM TRIUMPHIS INSIGNEM DICAVIT.

[Above central arch]
Imp(eratori) Caes(ari) Fl(avio) Constantino Maximo | P(io) F(elici) Augusto S(enatus) P(opulus)q(ue) R(omanus) | quod instinctu divinitatis mentis | magnitudine cum exercitu suo | tan de tyranno quan de omni eius | factione uno tempore iustis | rem publicam ultus est armis | arcum triumphis insignem dicavit.
[Above left arch]
Votis X
[Above right arch]
Votis XX
NOTE: In the 5th line of the inscription on the arch in this print, “tan” should be “tam” and “quan” should be “quam.” Compare with Source Text below.

〈:in utraque facie〉
Imp(eratori) Caes(ari) Fl(avio) Constantino Maximo
P(io) F(elici) Augusto, S(enatus) P(opulus)q(ue) R(omanus),
quod instinctu divinitatis, mentis
magnitudine, cum exercitu suo
tam de tyranno quam de omni eius
factione, uno tempore, iustis
rem publicam ultus est armis,
arcum triumphis insignem dicavit.
〈:in latere ad septentrionem verso〉
votis X votis XX.
〈:in latere ad meridionem verso〉
sic X sic XX.
〈:intra fornicem, ab una parte〉
liberatori urbis.
〈:intra fornicem, ab altera parte〉
fundatori quietis.
{CIL VI.1139 cf. VI 31245 et VI p. 3778 et VI p. 4328}

To the Emperor Caesar Flavius Constantinus Maximus Pius Felix Augustus, the Senate and the People of Rome dedicate this arch as a memorial to his military triumphs, who by the inspiration of divinity and his own genius avenged, with righteous arms in one instant, the Republic against the tyrant and his faction.

inscription.text: [Urbis Romae aedificorum illustriumque supersunt reliquae]

Traiani Imp. columna, cochlidis structura, in medio eius Foro, hodie quoq[ue] erecta visitur. Rerum a Traiano gestarum summa[m] mira arte caelatam habet: inprimis vero Dacicum bellu[m] intus 185 gradibus ad summu[m] fastigium, 40 fenestellis lucem admittentibus, ascensu[m] praebet. Alta pedu[m] 120 in summo Traiani ossa, in pila aurea condita servabantur.

Traiani Imperatoris columna, cochlidis structura, in medio eius Foro, hodie quoque erecta visitur. Rerum a Traiano gestarum summam mira arte caelatam habet: inprimis vero Dacicum bellum intus 185 gradibus ad summum fastigium, 40 fenestellis lucem admittentibus, ascensum praebet. Alta pedum 120 in summo Traiani ossa, in pila aurea condita servabantur.

Traiani Imp(eratoris) columna, cochlidis structura, in medio eius Foro, hodie quoq(ue) erecta visitur. Rerum a Traiano gestarum summa(m) mira arte caelatam habet: inprimis vero Dacicum bellu(m) intus 185 gradibus ad summu(m) fastigium, 40 fenestellis lucem admittentibus, ascensu(m) praebet. Alta pedu(m) 120 in summo Traiani ossa, in pila aurea condita servabantur.

The Column of the Emperor Trajan, spiral in structure, in the middle of his Forum, and which can still be seen standing today. It portrays the summary of the deeds carried out by Trajan, carved with great skill: first among them, the Dacian war. Within the column 185 steps allow one to ascend to the top of the pediment, with 40 small windows admitting light. At the top, at a height of 120 feet, the bones of Trajan used to be kept hidden within a golden sphere.
Senatus P Q R
Senatus Populusque Romanus

Senatus P(opulus)q(ue) R(omanus)
NOTE: On this print, only the beginning of the inscription on the base of the column is reproduced. See Source Text below for the full text of the inscription.

Senatus popolusque Romanus
Imp(eratori) Caesari dìvì Nervae f(ilio) Nervae
Traiano Aug(usto) Germ(anico) Dacico, pontif(ici)
maximo, trib(unicia) pot(estate) X̅V̅I̅I̅, imp(eratori) V̅I̅, co(n)s(uli) V̅I̅, p(atri) p(atriae),
ad declarandum, quantae altitudinis
mons et locus tant[is oper]ibus sit egestus.
{CIL VI.960 cf. VI p. 3070 et VI p. 3777 et VI p. 4310}

The Senate and People of Rome (dedicate this column) to the Emperor Caesar Nerva Trajan Augustus, son of the divine Nerva, Germanicus, Dacicus, pontifex maximus, invested with the tribunican power for the 17th time, proclaimed emperor six times, consul for the 6th time, father of the fatherland, as an illustration of the height of the hill that was demolished in the course of these great labors.

Columna Antonini Pii Imp. cochlidis structura, instar Traiani columnae, hodie in platea Columnae erecta visitur. Inter hanc columnam et porticum Antoninus Imp. palatium habuisse memoratur.

Columna Antonini Pii Imp[eratoris] cochlidis structura, instar Traiani columnae, hodie in platea Columnae erecta visitur. Inter hanc columnam et porticum Antoninus Imp[erator] palatium habuisse memoratur.

Column of emperor Antoninus Pius, with structure of a spiral shell, similar to Trajan’s column; today it is standing in the Columna street. It is recalled that emperor Antoninus had a palace between this column and the colonnade.

Pars quaedam interior ut nu[n]c cernitur Antonini Caracallae Thermarum ad Aventini montis radices, ubi nunc S. Balbinae templum conspicitur. Has inchoatas a Caracalla, perfectas et exornatas a Severo Imp., scribunt

Pars quaedam interior ut nunc cernitur Antonini Caracallae Thermarum ad Aventini montis radices, ubi nunc Sanctae Balbinae templum conspicitur. Has inchoatas a Caracalla, perfectas et exornatas a Severo Imperatore, scribunt

Pars quaedam interior ut nu[n]c cernitur Antonini Caracallae Thermarum ad Aventini montis radices, ubi nunc S[anctae] Balbinae templum conspicitur. Has inchoatas a Caracalla, perfectas et exornatas a Severo Imp[eratore], scribunt

Some interior part of the Baths of Antoninus Caracalla, as it is seen nowadays, at the foot of the Aventine Hill, where the temple of S. Balbina can be found today. It is written that they were initiated by Caracalla and finished and decorated by emperor Severus.

inscription.text: C. Cestii septemviri epulonum sepulchrum pyramidali forma hodie quoq[ue] integrum in via Ostiensi, prope portam nunc Sancti Pauli cernitur
Caii Cestii septemviri epulonum sepulchrum pyramidali forma hodie quoque integrum in via Ostiensi, prope portam nunc Sancti Pauli cernitur
C(aii) Cestii septemviri epulonum sepulchrum pyramidali forma hodie quoq(ue) integrum in via Ostiensi, prope portam nunc Sancti Pauli cernitur
Tomb of Caius Cestius, one of the Septemviri Epulonum, with pyramidal form; it still can be seen complete today in Via Ostiensis, next to the gate now called San Paolo.
C. CESTIUS L. F. POB. EPULO PR. TR. PL. VII VIR EPULONUM...OPUS APSOLUTUM EX TESTAMENTO DIEBUS CCC XXX ARBITRATU PONTI P. F. MELAE HAEREDIS ET PONTHI L.

CAIUS CESTIUS LUCII FILIUS Poblilia tribu EPULO PRAETOR TRIBUNUS PLEBIS VII VIR EPULONUM...OPUS APSOLUTUM EX TESTAMENTO DIEBUS CCCXXX ARBITRATU PONTI PUBLII FILII Claudia tribu MELAE HAEREDIS ET PONTHI LIBERTI.

C(aius) Cestius L(ucii) f(ilius) Pob(lilia) Epu | lo pr(aetor) tr(ibunus) pl(ebis) VII vir | Epulonum || Opus apsolutum ex testamento die | bus CCCXXX arbitratu | ponti P(ublii) f(ilii) Cla(udia) Melae haeredis et Pon | thi L(iberti).
NOTE: In the inscription on the print, “haeredis” should be spelled “heredis” and “Ponthi” should be spelled “Pothi.” In addition, due to spatial constraints the original line breaks in the inscription are not reproduced in this print. Compare with Source Text below.

〈:in latere ad Occidentem〉
C(aius) Cestius L(uci) f(ilius) Pob(lilia) Epulo, pr(aetor), tr(ibunus) pl(ebis),
VIIvir epulonum.
〈:in latere ad Orientem〉
C(aius) Cestius L(uci) f(ilius) Pob(lilia) Epulo, pr(aetor), tr(ibunus) pl(ebis),
VIIvir epulonum.
Opus apsolutum ex testamento diebus CCCXXX
arbitratu
[L(uci)] Ponti P(ubli) f(ili) Cla(udia) Melae, heredis, et Pothi l(iberti).
{CIL VI 1374 cf. VI 31639 et VI p. 3805 et VI p. 4688}

Caius Cestius Epulo, son of Lucius, from the tribe Publilia, praetor, plebeian tribune, one of the seven priests in charge of religious banquets (is buried here)... The work was completed in 330 days, in accordance with the will of the deceased, under the direction of Pontius Mela, Publius's son and heir from the tribe Claudia, and of the freedman Pothos.

inscription.text: [Urbis Romae aedificorum illustriumque supersunt reliquae]

Moles, quam Hadrianus Imp. iuxta Aelium pontem, e regione Mausolei Augusti, pro suo sepulchro excitavit in quo primu[m] ipsius, postea omnium Antoninoru[m] cineres sunt reconditi hodie pontificum praesidiu[m] est, appellaturq[ue], ut nunc cernitur, Castello S. Agnolo

Moles, quam Hadrianus Imperator iuxta Aelium pontem, e regione Mausolei Augusti, pro suo sepulchro excitavit in quo primum ipsius, postea omnium Antoninorum cineres sunt reconditi hodie pontificum praesidium est, appellaturque, ut nunc cernitur, Castello Sant' Agnolo

Moles, quam Hadrianus Imp[erator] iuxta Aelium pontem, e regione Mausolei Augusti, pro suo sepulchro excitavit in quo primu[m] ipsius, postea omnium Antoninoru[m] cineres sunt reconditi hodie pontificum praesidiu[m] est, appellaturq[ue], ut nunc cernitur, Castello S[ant'] Agnolo

Massive structure that emperor Hadrian erected next to the Pons Aelius, from the direction of the Mausoleum of Augustus, to be his own tomb in which first his ashes, then, those of every Antoninus, were hidden; today it is the fortress of the Popes, and it is called, as it is seen today, Castel Sant’Angelo.

inscription.text: [Urbis Romae aedificorum illustriumque supersunt reliquae]

Extra portam Capenam, hodie S. Sebastiani, Via Appia secu[n]do miliario Circus ab Antonino Caracalla extructus fuit, cuius ingentes ruinae, et inter eas obeliscus, metarumq[ue] vestigia non procul ab aede S. Sebastiani cernuntur

Extra portam Capenam, hodie Sancti Sebastiani, Via Appia secundo miliario Circus ab Antonino Caracalla extructus fuit, cuius ingentes ruinae, et inter eas obeliscus, metarumque vestigia non procul ab aede Sancti Sebastiani cernuntur

Extra portam Capenam, hodie S[ancti] Sebastiani, Via Appia secu[n]do miliario Circus ab Antonino Caracalla extructus fuit, cuius ingentes ruinae, et inter eas obeliscus, metarumq[ue] vestigia non procul ab aede S[ancti] Sebastiani cernuntur

Beyond the Porta Capena, today S. Sebastiano, at the second milestone on the Via Appia, a circus was built by Antoninus Caracalla whose vast ruins, the obelisks among them, and traces of its goals can be seen not far from the temple of S. Sebastiano.

marks (symbols)
Extra portam Capenam, Via Appia, ad secundu[m] lapide[m] sepulchru[m] fuit Metelloru[m], cuius memin[it] Cicero. Id cernitur hodie, ubi dicitur ad Caput bovis, parum ultra Circum Caracallae
Extra portam Capenam, Via Appia, ad secundum lapidem sepulchrum fuit Metellorum, cuius meminit Cicero. Id cernitur hodie, ubi dicitur ad Caput bovis, parum ultra Circum Caracallae
Extra portam Capenam, Via Appia, ad secundu(m) lapide(m) sepulchru(m) fuit Metelloru(m), cuius memin(it) Cicero. Id cernitur hodie, ubi dicitur ad Caput bovis, parum ultra Circum Caracallae

Beyond the Porta Capena, on the Via Appia, at the second stone, there was the tomb of the Metelli, whom Cicero mentioned. It is seen today at the place that is called the Caput Bovis, a little bit further than the Circus of Caracalla.
CAECILIAE Q. CRETICI F. METELLAE CRASSI
Caeciliae Quinti Cretici filiae Metellae Crassi
Caeciliae | Q(uinti) Cretici f(iliae) | Metellae Crassi

inscription.text: Veduta dell'Isola di S. Bartolomeo
View of the Island of San Bartolomeo

j Isola di S. Bartolomeo sul Tevere, anticamente licaonia, dedicata a Giove licaonio et ad Esculapio fabricata in forma di nave
2 Chiesa e Campanile di S. Bartolomeo
3 Ponte fabritio, hoggi Ponte Quattro Capi, per esservi un Giano quadrifronte
4 Ponte Cesto, hoggi di S. Bartolomeo, conduce in Trastevere
5 Ponte rotte di S. Maria, detto anticamente Senatorio
6 Veduta di Trastevere
7 Cupola della Chiesa della Trinita di Ponte Sisto, dentro la Città

j Island of San Bartolomeo on the Tiber, formerly called Licaonia, having been dedicated to Jove Lykaios and to Aesclepius, built in the form of a ship
2 The Church and belltower of San Bartolomeo
3 Pons Fabricius, today the Ponte Quattro Capi, named for the four-headed Janus
4 Pons Cestius, today called S. Bartolomeo, which leads to Trastevere
5 The broken bridge of Santa Maria, formerly called 'Senatorio'
6 View of Trastevere
7 Dome of the Church of the Trinity by Ponte Sisto, inside the city
Gio Iacomo Rossi le stampa in Roma alla pace co Pr. del S.P.

inscription.text: L'arco di Settimio, il Tempio di Gioue Statore, & Campidoglio.
L'arco di Settimio, il Tempio di Gioue Statore, & Campidoglio.
The Arch of Septimius, the Temple of Jupiter Stator, and the Campidoglio.
Guil.mo van Nieuw'lant fecit et excud. Antuerpiae.
Guglielmo van Nieuwlant fecit et excudit Antuerpiae.
Gu(gl)i(e)lmo van Nieuwlant fecit et excud(it) Antuerpiae.
William van Nieulandt made this and published it in Antwerp.
IMP. CESAR SETIMIO FIL. SEVERO... S.P.Q.R.
Imperatori Caesari Septimio filio Severo... Senatus Populusque Romanus

Imp(eratori) C(a)esar(i) Se(p)timio fil(io) Severo | ... | ... S(enatus) P(opulus)q(ue) R(omanus)
NOTE: This print only includes the beginning and the end of the inscription as it appears on the Arch of Septimius Severus. See Source Text below. The full inscription can also be found on prints A12, A38, A56, C404.

Ìmp(eratori) Caes(ari) Lucio Septimio M(arci) fil(io) Severo Pio Pertinaci Aug(usto) patri patriae Parthico Arabico et
Parthico Adiabenico, pontific(i) maximo, tribunic(ia) potest(ate) X̅I̅, ìmp(eratori) X̅I̅, co(n)s(uli) I̅I̅I̅, proco(n)s(uli) et
Ìmp(eratori) Caes(ari) M(arco) Aurelio L(uci) fil(io) Antonino Aug(usto) Pio Felici, tribunic(ia) potest(ate) V̅I̅, co(n)s(uli), proco(n)s(uli), 《p(atri) p(atriae)》,
《optimis fortissimisque principibus》
5 ob rem publicam restitutam imperiumque populi Romani propagatum
insignibus virtutibus eorum domi forisque s(enatus) p(opulus)q(ue) R(omanus).
{CIL VI.1033 cf. VI 31230 et VI 36881 et VI p. 4318 et VI p. 4351 (ad 36881)}

To the Emperor Caesar Lucius Septimius Severus, son of Marcus, Pius, Pertinax, Augustus, Pater Patriae, Parthicus Arabicus and Parthicus Adiabenicus, Pontifex Maximus, granted the Tribunician power for the eleventh time, acclaimed victorius general for the eleventh time, consul for the third time, proconsul; and to the Emperor Caesar Marcus Aurelius Antoninus, son of Lucius, Augustus, Pius, Felix, granted the Tribunician power for the sixth time, consul, proconsul, Pater Patriae; to both men, the best and bravest emperors, for having saved the Republic and expanded the dominion of the Roman people and for their remarkable virtue, at home and abroad, the Senate and the People of Rome (dedicate this arch).
